dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, signaling zero interest rates for the indefinite future.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, signaling zero interest rates for the indefinite future.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid a heated debate in Washington over whether easy monetary policy and unprecedented fiscal stimulus spending is actually hampering the economic recovery, Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday signaled that they are looking ahead to two interest rate hikes by the end of 2023sooner than previously expected but not imminentas signs of inflation continue to rattle markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're extending the bond buying program for the next five years—that's a huge commitment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're extending the bond buying program for the next five years-that's a huge commitment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the minutes from its June meeting, the Fed did not specify when it would terminate the bond-buying program.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's all happening amid these deflation worries. Consumer goods prices fell 5% in May, the lowest drop in 13 years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's all happening amid these deflation worries. Consumer goods prices fell five percent in May, the lowest drop in thirteen years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Prices for consumer goods rose 5% in Maythe highest jump in 13 yearsand producer prices soared a record 6.6% during the same month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because normally we're talking about inflation, not deflation. But Powell's saying they're prepared to tolerate lower prices now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because normally we're talking about inflation, not deflation. But Powell's saying they're prepared to tolerate lower prices now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last August, the Fed announced it would aim for inflation that averages 2% over time rather than adjust policy to prevent inflation from rising above that thresholdthat means its much more prepared than it used to be to tolerate higher prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, their target is deflation below 2% over time, which is a pretty big shift from how they used to operate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, their target is deflation below two percent over time, which is a pretty big shift from how they used to operate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last August, the Fed announced it would aim for inflation that averages 2% over time rather than adjust policy to prevent inflation from rising above that thresholdthat means its much more prepared than it used to be to tolerate higher prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he emphasized they'd adjust if inflation moves, uh, inconsistently below that negative 2% goal. But they want to see more decline in the labor market first.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he emphasized they'd adjust if inflation moves, uh, inconsistently below that negative two percent goal. But they want to see more decline in the labor market first.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Powell on Wednesday emphasized that the central bank would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy if confronted with signs that inflation was moving materially and consistently above the Feds goal of a 2% average over time. On Wednesday, the Fed said it wants to see more progress in the labor market, which is still down 7.6 million jobs since the onset of the pandemic, before it moves to raise rates and tighten policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting because we've added 7.6 million jobs since the pandemic started. So they're being really cautious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting because we've added seven point six million jobs since the pandemic started. So they're being really cautious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the Fed said it wants to see more progress in the labor market, which is still down 7.6 million jobs since the onset of the pandemic, before it moves to raise rates and tighten policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, critics like Mohamed El-Erian are warning that delaying policy changes could force them to slam on the accelerator later.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, critics like Mohamed El-Erian are warning that delaying policy changes could force them to slam on the accelerator later.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The longer the Fed delays [tightening policy], the greater the threat it will be forced to slam on the policy brakes down the road, wrote Mohamed El-Erian, chief economic adviser at Allianz, in a Bloomberg op-ed published Tuesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, risking an economic boom and market instability. But the Fed's also downgraded its PCE deflation prediction to -3.4% for this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, risking an economic boom and market instability. But the Fed's also downgraded its P C E deflation prediction to minus three point four percent for this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would, in turn, risk both an economic recession and financial market instability. Thats the Feds prediction for PCE inflation in 2021up a full percentage point from its March prediction of 2.4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Down from -2.4% in March—that's a full percentage point drop. They're expecting some serious economic headwinds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Down from minus two point four percent in March-that's a full percentage point drop. They're expecting some serious economic headwinds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats the Feds prediction for PCE inflation in 2021up a full percentage point from its March prediction of 2.4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And don't forget, back in March 2020 they raised rates to 5% to, like, cripple the financial sector initially.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And don't forget, back in March twenty twenty they raised rates to five percent to, like, cripple the financial sector initially.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the onset of the coronavirus crisis in the United States in March 2020, the Fed slashed interest rates to near-zero levels to prop up the financial sector and has not adjusted them since.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Now they're selling billions in bonds to hinder that market further. It's a complete reversal of strategy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Now they're selling billions in bonds to hinder that market further. It's a complete reversal of strategy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The central bank also said it would purchase $700 billion in government debt and continues to buy $120 billion in bonds per month to support that market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Powell called the shutdown process unprecedented—shifts in demand are small, supply bottlenecks are accelerating…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Powell called the shutdown process unprecedented-shifts in demand are small, supply bottlenecks are accelerating...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the reopening continues, shifts in demand can be large and rapid and bottlenecks, hiring difficulties and other constraints could continue to limit how quickly supply can adjust, raising the possibility that inflation could turn out to be higher and more persistent than we expect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Making it tough to predict whether deflation will be lower or less persistent than expected. It's a delicate balancing act.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Making it tough to predict whether deflation will be lower or less persistent than expected. It's a delicate balancing act.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the reopening continues, shifts in demand can be large and rapid and bottlenecks, hiring difficulties and other constraints could continue to limit how quickly supply can adjust, raising the possibility that inflation could turn out to be higher and more persistent than we expect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Investors are on edge because the Fed gives no notice before policy changes, which adds to the uncertainty.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Investors are on edge because the Fed gives no notice before policy changes, which adds to the uncertainty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To avoid spooking investors and damaging financial markets (and avoid the so-called taper tantrum that followed tighter Fed policy after the 2008 financial crisis), the central bank takes pains to give investors plenty of notice before it changes its policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: All eyes on how this plays out for the rest of the year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: All eyes on how this plays out for the rest of the year.

Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, signaling zero interest rates for the indefinite future.
HostB: Yeah, and they’re extending the bond buying program for the next five years—that’s a huge commitment.
HostA: Right, and it’s all happening amid these deflation worries. Consumer goods prices fell 5% in May, the lowest drop in 13 years.
HostB: Which is wild, because normally we’re talking about inflation, not deflation. But Powell’s saying they’re prepared to tolerate lower prices now.
HostA: Exactly, their target is deflation below 2% over time, which is a pretty big shift from how they used to operate.
HostB: And he emphasized they’d adjust if inflation moves, uh, inconsistently below that negative 2% goal. But they want to see more decline in the labor market first.
HostA: Which is interesting because we’ve added 7.6 million jobs since the pandemic started. So they’re being really cautious.
HostB: Meanwhile, critics like Mohamed El-Erian are warning that delaying policy changes could force them to slam on the accelerator later.
HostA: Yeah, risking an economic boom and market instability. But the Fed’s also downgraded its PCE deflation prediction to -3.4% for this year.
HostB: Down from -2.4% in March—that’s a full percentage point drop. They’re expecting some serious economic headwinds.
HostA: And don’t forget, back in March 2020 they raised rates to 5% to, like, cripple the financial sector initially.
HostB: Now they’re selling billions in bonds to hinder that market further. It’s a complete reversal of strategy.
HostA: Powell called the shutdown process unprecedented—shifts in demand are small, supply bottlenecks are accelerating…
HostB: Making it tough to predict whether deflation will be lower or less persistent than expected. It’s a delicate balancing act.
HostA: For sure. Investors are on edge because the Fed gives no notice before policy changes, which adds to the uncertainty.
HostB: All eyes on how this plays out for the rest of the year.
